title: How long will the MacBook Pro 2019 last? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for asking. I typically get around 5 years of use as a primary computer (4 under warranty with the extended AppleCare that takes the standard 1 year and adds 3). I usually stretch it another year with supported updates from Apple, and then effectively indefinite use as a secondary machine. Some supporting detail: You’ve got your warranty, and if you take the AppleCare extension, it’s good to take it in and get it checked over before that runs out (three additional years!). The current Pros, both 13 and 15, are also well equipped in terms of being powerful enough to keep handling additional work over the effective lifetime of the hardware, assuming you pick the right amount of storage and RAM. Since you are asking about how long it will last, I would also suggest that you err on the side of more RAM and storage space. Additional storage space in the solid state drive will also actually make it last longer, as current technology does actually wear, and the wear-leveling algorithm to distribute wear works better if there’s more empty space. Now, that said, you can damage it unrepairably by physical damage or abuse or just bad luck and wear. Here’s couple of data points: My elderly MacBook Pro 15 is completely dead, likely the thermal GPU failure that particular year was known for. I bought it used, replaced the battery, and for years of use out of it, so it doesn’t owe me anything, and it’s so old it’s only barely worth repairing. My 2009 iMac is still running well; I upgraded the RAM and replaced the hard drive that was failing when it was 5 years old, and Apple kept supporting that model with releases for another 3 years. There’s no guarantee that the 2019 model will have 8 years of support, but from a “will it have the hardware that’s mainstream enough to keep supporting” perspective, it’s in a relatively recent hardware generation, so it should be similar enough to the next few years that it makes economic sense for Apple to keep supporting it.
